Disclosures Involving Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Assessments
Access Provisions Applicable to Disclosure of TFRP
Involving Trust Fund Recovery Penalty 11.3.40
) Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) provides guidance on aspects relating to the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP). (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees. (
) Policy Owner: The Director of Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and guards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (

) Program Owner: The Disclosure office, under GLDS, is responsible for the closure program and guidance. Each IRS organization is responsible for ensuring its employees are aware of and follow Servicewide Disclosure (
) Primary Stakeholders: The following offices have responsibility for pertaining to Trust Fund Penalty Assessments made pursuant to IRC
• Small Business/Self Employed (SBSE) • Appeals • Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) (
) The disclosure guidance provided in this section applies to the collection taxes subject to IRC
In the case of employment taxes, IRC
is limited to the trust fund portion of the tax; that is, to the tax that the sible person is required to collect or withhold from the wages of In the case of excise taxes, IRC

(a) is applied according to the plain language of the statute: the penalty equal to the total amount of the tax evaded, or not collected, or not accounted for and paid over. This also applies to the personal liability imposed by IRC
against persons willfully causing a business entity to fail to pay certain excise taxes (for example the air transportation excise taxes under IRC
and IRC (

) The same care should be exercised in disclosures involving collected tax assessment records as is exercised in disclosing TFRP assessment records. Careful consideration of the complicated relationships involved in these assessments is necessary prior to disclosure of any information. (
) The following items govern the authority pertaining to the disclosures of information: • IRC
• IRC
(a) • IRC

requests for access to TFRP records. Internal Revenue Manual
Purpose: This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) provides guidance on disclosure aspects relating to the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP).
Primary Stakeholders: The following offices have responsibility for disclosures pertaining to Trust Fund Penalty Assessments made pursuant to IRC 6672

This IRM is intended to provide Collection or other compliance employees with information about their responsibilities in releasing TFRP penalty information. It is also meant to enable Disclosure personnel to provide advice and assistance to Revenue Officers, Appeals Officers and others engaged in the assessment, collection and litigation of such penalties and for Disclosure personnel to process Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and Internal Revenue Code IRC
requests for access to TFRP records.
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
Note: See IRM 11.3.2.4.14, Trust Fund Recovery Penalties and IRM below for in- formation on disclosures of TFRP information pursuant to IRC 6103(e)(9)
The following is a list of the terms and acronyms that are used in this IRM
The following is a list of the terms and acronyms that are used in this IRM Section:

Section: Terms and Deﬁnitions Term Deﬁnition Disclosure The making known to any person in any manner whatever, a return or return information. See IRC 6103(b)(8) Material Interest An important interest which is generally, but not always, ﬁnancial in nature. However, in the legal sense, the interest needs to be substantial or of con- sequence. Return Any tax or information return, declaration of estimated tax, or claim for refund required by, or provided for or permitted under, the provisions of Title 26 6103 which is ﬁled with the Secretary by, on behalf of, or with respect to any person, and any amendment or supplement thereto, including supporting schedules, attachments, or lists which are supplemental to, or part of, the return so ﬁled. See IRC 6103(b)(1) Return Information The deﬁnition of return informa- tion is very broad and includes such things as a taxpayer’s identity, the nature, source, or amount of a taxpayer’s income, payments, receipts, deductions, exemptions, credits, assets, li- abilities, net worth, tax liability tax withheld, deﬁciencies, overass- essments, or tax payments; whether the taxpayer’s returns is subject to collection, examination, investigation, or any other actions taken by the Secretary with respect to federal ﬁling require- ments. See IRC 6103(b)(2) for the statutory deﬁnition.

Disclosures Involving Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Assessments 11.3.40
11.3.40.1.5 (09-18-2020) Related Resources

Citation Title Guidance IRM 5.7.6 Trust Fund Penalty Provides guidance to Assessment Action Collection employees for the processing of the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) cases, including protests and quick and prompt as- sessment actions.

4 11.3 Disclosure of Official Information Citation Title Guidance IRM 11.3.2 Disclosure to Provides a listing of Persons with a persons who may Material Interest generally request and receive returns and return information IRC 6103 (e)(1)(6) and IRC 6103(e)(10) concern disclosures of “returns” IRC 6103(e)(7) through IRC 6103(e)(9) IRM 11.3.13 Freedom of Informa- Provides guidance tion Act (FOIA) when disclosure is requested through the Freedom of Informa- tion Act IRM 11.3.22 Disclosure to Federal Provides guidance on Officers and disclosure of returns Employees for Tax and return information Administration for tax administration Purposes purpose under IRC 6103(h) (1) IRC 6672 provides that any person required to collect, truthfully account for, and pay over any tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code who willfully fails Basis of Trust to do so or willfully attempts in any manner to evade or defeat any such tax or Recovery Penalty the payment thereof, shall in addition to other penalties provided by law, be (TFRP) liable for a penalty equal to the total amount of the tax. (2) The TFRP provisions are administered by the Collection function of the Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) division. (3) Procedural instructions appear in IRM 5.7, Trust Fund Compliance. Additional information is provided in IRM 5.17.7, Liability of Third Parties for Unpaid Em- ployment Taxes. (4) The most common TFRP assessments are against one or more persons who are or were associated with a corporation or LLC that failed to pay a covered tax such as an employment tax. (1) At any point in the TFRP process, employees may receive a request for access to the ﬁles. Each request must be considered based on the current Disclosure status of the case, whether taxes have been proposed or assessed, and the statutory provision under which the request is made. Requests for access to TFRP ﬁles may occur during the TFRP investigation but may also be after the assessment has taken place, and the assessment may be against one or more of the identiﬁed persons or there may be some that were considered but not assessed. That is a key component to know when reviewing access rights in a TFRP ﬁle.

provides that any person required to collect, truthfully account and pay over any tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code who willfully to do so or willfully attempts in any manner to evade or defeat any such the payment thereof, shall in addition to other penalties provided by law, liable for a penalty equal to the total amount of the tax. The most common TFRP assessments are against one or more persons are or were associated with a corporation or LLC that failed to pay a tax such as an employment tax. At any point in the TFRP process, employees may receive a request for access to the ﬁles. Each request must be considered based on the current status of the case, whether taxes have been proposed or assessed, and statutory provision under which the request is made. Requests for access TFRP ﬁles may occur during the TFRP investigation but may also be after assessment has taken place, and the assessment may be against one or of the identiﬁed persons or there may be some that were considered but assessed. IRC 6672 provides that any person required to collect, truthfully account for, and pay over any tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code who willfully fails to do so or willfully attempts in any manner to evade or defeat any such tax or the payment thereof, shall in addition to other penalties provided by law, be
Procedural instructions appear in IRM 5.7, Trust Fund Compliance. Additional information is provided in IRM 5.17.7, Liability of Third Parties for Unpaid Em-

At any point in the TFRP process, employees may receive a request for access to the ﬁles. Each request must be considered based on the current status of the case, whether taxes have been proposed or assessed, and the statutory provision under which the request is made. Requests for access to TFRP ﬁles may occur during the TFRP investigation but may also be after the assessment has taken place, and the assessment may be against one or more of the identiﬁed persons or there may be some that were considered but not assessed. That is a key component to know when reviewing access rights in a
Involving Trust Fund Recovery Penalty

) Persons subject to the penalty may at one time have been closely in the business; they may be friends or relatives; they may at times have erated with each other and jointly proposed alternatives to the penalty; or, openly or covertly have become adversaries seeking to avoid the penalty at each other’s expense. Such relationships are irrelevant for Disclosure purposes. (

) Each person subject to the penalty is a separate taxpayer whose rights of access to records and whose right to privacy must be separately evaluated without regard to apparent personal relationships with another person to the penalty. (

) The close relationship between the persons who may be subject to penalty would generally mean that most of the information concerning any one of is already known to one or more of the others. Such prior knowledge does serve to authorize the disclosure of records which are not otherwise available. (
) Disclosure and Collection personnel should recognize that TFRP ﬁles and related information may be available under FOIA, or pursuant to IRC (e)(
) or (e)(
). Third party information cannot be disclosed IRC
) in response to a FOIA request. See Exhibit for a brief tion of each access provision. Note: See IRM
, Trust Fund Recovery Penalties, for a discussion of how to respond to requests citing both the FOIA and IRC

) Persons under investigation as potential responsible persons may, as a of the investigatory process, learn information such as the identity of other persons under investigation. Such circumstances do not authorize additional disclosures and do not create a right to receive conﬁrmation of information learned or surmised. (

) Records produced or maintained in connection with the TFRP assessment return information of the person or entity involved. Note: Records gathered or generated with respect to determining the liability of entity are the return information of the entity, and not that of any person vestigated as a potentially responsible person. Similarly, records gathered generated with the respect to determining a person’s status as a person are the return information of that person and not of the entity or of any other person. (
) Different persons may be subject to the penalty for different periods. This result in variations in their right to records. (
) Having determined that a record is the return information of a taxpayer, that record will be available to any person who has established a material as provided by IRC
(e), unless it is to be withheld pursuant to IRC
) when release would impair tax administration or identify a tial informant. Internal Revenue Manual

Involving Trust Fund Recovery Penalty 11.3.40

) There are various records contained in a TFRP case. The following sections discuss the types of information or documents that may be involved, as well Involved access to and release of the information or documents. (

) Generally, TFRP cases begin with an attempt to collect employment or taxes from the business which was initially responsible for the ﬁling and/or Case File payment of such taxes. The business case ﬁle in connection with the tion or collection activity is the return or return information of the business. (

) If a FOIA request for the TFRP investigation ﬁle is received along with a request for the complete business case ﬁle the portion pertaining to the business case ﬁle should be worked following regular FOIA processing lines including the application of IRC
(e) as appropriate. See IRM Disclosure of Official Information, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) . Collec- tion employees receiving a request for access should also apply IRC
(e) as appropriate, such as disclosure to an individual as authorized under IRC
)(A). See IRM
, Disclosure to Persons with a Material or Exhibit , for more information. (

) FOIA access to TFRP documents contained in the business case ﬁle is to persons against whom the penalty has been proposed or assessed and limited to documents relevant to determining that person’s liability. Any tion in the business case ﬁle pertaining to the determination that a TFRP should be assessed against a person is return information of only that subject to the penalty. The return or return information of a corporation is available to: a. a corporate officer authorized in accordance with State law to legally the corporation; b. any person designated by resolution of its board of directors or any similar governing body; c. any officer or employee of the corporation upon written request signed any principal officer and attested to by the secretary or other officer; or
)(A). See IRM

, Disclosure to Persons with a Material Interest, or Exhibit , for more information. FOIA access to TFRP documents contained in the business case ﬁle is limited to persons against whom the penalty has been proposed or assessed and limited to documents relevant to determining that person’s liability. Any informa- tion in the business case ﬁle pertaining to the determination that a TFRP should be assessed against a person is return information of only that person subject to the penalty. The return or return information of a corporation is available to:

access to TFRP documents contained in the business case ﬁle is limited persons against whom the penalty has been proposed or assessed and to documents relevant to determining that person’s liability. Any in the business case ﬁle pertaining to the determination that a TFRP be assessed against a person is return information of only that person to the penalty. The return or return information of a corporation is

a corporate officer authorized in accordance with State law to legally bind the corporation; any person designated by resolution of its board of directors or any other similar governing body; any officer or employee of the corporation upon written request signed by any principal officer and attested to by the secretary or other officer; or a bona ﬁde shareholder of record owning one percent or more of the out
standing stock of the corporation.

FOIA requesters seeking TFRP documents contained in the business case ﬁle who are not subject to investigation or who have been determined not to be subject to the penalty may not receive access to the business case ﬁle except as otherwise provided in IRC
(e). Also see IRM

If a person under investigation as a potential responsible party executes a POA for only the 1st quarter 2011 TFRP (6672 Penalty/Civil Penalty), the attorney will be able to inspect/receive the person’s return and return information to the extent authorized under IRC 6103(e). The attorney will
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
be able to inspect/receive business related documents found in the TFRP investigation ﬁle directly related to the 1st quarter 2011 TFRP if the person has been assessed.

st quarter
TFRP if the person has been assessed. Note: If the authorization does not cover income taxes, Form
, you cannot release information in relation to income taxes. (

) The contents of the TFRP ﬁles are generally not the return information of business, although some supporting documents may consist of copies of records which originated in the business case ﬁle and were, in their original form and are, even after copying into a responsible person’s TFRP case return information of the business. (

) TFRP case ﬁles consist of documents prepared or maintained to support justify the penalty assessment and may contain return information of one, several, or all persons subject to, or potentially subject to, the penalty. a. TFRP ﬁles that involve more than one responsible person, or potential responsible person, are generally organized so that a primary or “key” and a number of supplemental, or secondary ﬁles are created. b. All penalty determination documents are placed in the primary ﬁle documents that pertain to a potential responsible person are placed in speciﬁc supplemental ﬁle, pertaining solely to each potentially person. c. If Disclosure personnel request a TFRP investigation ﬁle for all TFRP and/or related ﬁles and only receive a secondary or supplemental ﬁle, they will have to make another request to secure the primary ﬁle and ensure receipt of all documents. Note: See IRM
, Case File Documentation, for a list of that may be found in a TFRP investigation ﬁle. (

) Records and information gathered or generated in the course of whether a speciﬁc person is a responsible person subject to the TFRP is return information of that person. Such information is available to that in accordance with IRC
(e). Such information is generally not available the business or to any other person. (

) Information obtained from a person being investigated for possible TFRP liability, with respect to that person’s potential liability, is the return of that person. This is true even if the information refers to other persons may also be liable for the same TFRP. The original provider may obtain a of what he/she provided even if it contains third party references. Note: Care should be taken that any release consist only of what was said by received from the original provider. Note: Redact notations made by IRS personnel on documents submitted to the original provider. (

) Information obtained from a person with respect to the potential liability of another person for the TFRP penalty is the return information of the person whose liability is the reason the information was obtained or received. This true even if the provider of the information is also potentially responsible for Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
M
Note: If the authorization does not cover income taxes, Form 1040, you cannot release information in relation to income taxes.

The contents of the TFRP ﬁles are generally not the return information of the business, although some supporting documents may consist of copies of records which originated in the business case ﬁle and were, in their original form and are, even after copying into a responsible person’s TFRP case ﬁle, return information of the business. TFRP case ﬁles consist of documents prepared or maintained to support and justify the penalty assessment and may contain return information of one, several, or all persons subject to, or potentially subject to, the penalty. a. TFRP ﬁles that involve more than one responsible person, or potential responsible person, are generally organized so that a primary or “key” ﬁle and a number of supplemental, or secondary ﬁles are created. b. All penalty determination documents are placed in the primary ﬁle while documents that pertain to a potential responsible person are placed in a speciﬁc supplemental ﬁle, pertaining solely to each potentially responsible person. c. If Disclosure personnel request a TFRP investigation ﬁle for all TFRP and/or related ﬁles and only receive a secondary or supplemental ﬁle, they will have to make another request to secure the primary ﬁle and ensure receipt of all documents. , Case File Documentation, for a list of documents

a. TFRP ﬁles that involve more than one responsible person, or potential responsible person, are generally organized so that a primary or “key” and a number of supplemental, or secondary ﬁles are created. b. All penalty determination documents are placed in the primary ﬁle while documents that pertain to a potential responsible person are placed in a speciﬁc supplemental ﬁle, pertaining solely to each potentially person. c. ) Records and information gathered or generated in the course of determining whether a speciﬁc person is a responsible person subject to the TFRP is the return information of that person. Such information is available to that person in accordance with IRC
(e). Such information is generally not available to the business or to any other person. (

) Information obtained from a person being investigated for possible TFRP liability, with respect to that person’s potential liability, is the return information of that person. This is true even if the information refers to other persons who may also be liable for the same TFRP. The original provider may obtain a copy of what he/she provided even if it contains third party references.

Information obtained from a person being investigated for possible TFRP liability, with respect to that person’s potential liability, is the return information of that person. This is true even if the information refers to other persons who may also be liable for the same TFRP. The original provider may obtain a copy of what he/she provided even if it contains third party references.
Note: Care should be taken that any release consist only of what was said by received from the original provider.
Note: Redact notations made by IRS personnel on documents submitted to the original provider.

Information obtained from a person with respect to the potential liability of another person for the TFRP penalty is the return information of the person whose liability is the reason the information was obtained or received. This is true even if the provider of the information is also potentially responsible for
Involving Trust Fund Recovery Penalty 11.3.40
page 9

the same TFRP. Consideration should be given as to whether the release of the information to the person whose liability is being considered, could impair an investigation, identify an informant or otherwise be exempt from disclosure. (

) History notes from TFRP ﬁles are often difficult to review and sanitize, espe- cially when multiple persons are considered for assertion of the TFRP. ) While Collection compliance employees are conducting a TFRP investigation, issues involving investigative disclosures, joint appearances, informal by and/or oral disclosures may arise. Employees (

) Investigative disclosures are made at the initiative of the IRS in the process of obtaining information, collecting tax or performing law enforcement activities. Disclosure They cannot be made in response to a taxpayer’s request to obtain informa- tion. Investigative disclosures are not authorized for the purpose of obtaining greater cooperation from the taxpayer and cannot be offered as a trade-off for other information.

Investigative disclosures are made at the initiative of the IRS in the process of obtaining information, collecting tax or performing law enforcement activities. They cannot be made in response to a taxpayer’s request to obtain informa
tion. Investigative disclosures are not authorized for the purpose of obtaining greater cooperation from the taxpayer and cannot be offered as a trade

) Each person subject to the TFRP may be a valid source of information con- cerning other persons subject to the penalty. Consequently, such person easily infer the identity of other persons involved. Such inference does not authorize further disclosure of information and should not be conﬁrmed. (

) The process of asserting the TFRP may include conferences with persons subject to the penalty. Several or all of the persons subject to the penalty appear at such conferences. Appearing jointly creates an atmosphere where Collection employees must be sensitive to the privacy considerations of participant. ) Disclosure personnel will provide any necessary advice to accomplish the quickest and least expensive resolution of any request. (

) Telephonic contact with the requester is strongly encouraged in order to the extent and intent of the request, explain the type of information which be released and reduce the effort and expense necessary to resolve the request. (

) Requests that formally cite FOIA must be processed by the Disclosure office. In situations where the requester agrees, the Revenue Officer or Appeals Officer may respond if the formal FOIA request is withdrawn. (
